awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase II: Grid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Grid-Connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES) IUCRC proposes renewal as a two-site I/UCRC, comprising personnel and facilities at the University of Arkansas (lead) and the University of South Carolina with a focus on developing the new knowledge, tools, hardware, software, and personnel that are required to pervasively insert power electronics into the 21st century power grid in ways that will strengthen and modernize the grid. GRAPES makes use of an already-developed facility for design, development, 
test, evaluation, and standardization of distribution-level grid-connected power electronic equipment. This enables validation of research findings, and accelerated insertion of new solid-state equipment into the power grid at both source and load ends. 

Power electronics in grid applications are essential to achieving efficient power systems of high reliability and resiliency. The I/UCRC in Phase II will train students and practicing engineers who will become qualified to develop and manage the next generation of power systems, thereby helping to mitigate the forecasted shortage of power engineers. GRAPES will establish new courses that will integrate research with education to make our students highly competitive in their ownership of unique skills and knowledge.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Modernization and greening of the electric power grid require pervasive use of power electronic components and systems but many practical and technical obstacles have impeded widespread deployment of power electronics technologies. Research at this site of the GRAPES center has developed methods to improve stability of power from wind farms, compensate for non-periodic currents that can be introduced by heavy industries such as steel-making plants, developed hierarchical control structures to improve power quality near photovoltaic power installations, provide fault protection in dc microgrids powered by solar and battery components, and improve the reliability of electronic power converters. The project has also improved capabilities for early warning of impending failures in aging electric power cables, developed new methods to improve voltage regulation in local branches of a power distribution system that would otherwise be adversely affected by conflicting adjustments between automatic tap-changing power transformers and solar power resources, and developed probabilistic algorithms for optimizing the placement of photovoltaic power sources along distribution feeders.

Broader impacts of this research include development of the BS, MS, and PhD-level workforce with expertise in electrical engineering, and especially in the critical space related to power electronics, power systems, and digital controls. A total of nine graduate students and eleven undergraduate students developed new skills by participating in these projects. Four of the undergraduate students continued to graduate school here, and another four joined graduate schools elsewhere.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2024
Modified by: Roger A Dougal
